snippet: Mandatory financial oversight has come as a result of millions in uncollected fees, a flight of the city’s affluent tax base and hopes that downturns might melt away.
abstract: Financial crisis that has made Detroit one of the largest cities ever to face mandatory state oversight was decades in the making; trail of missteps, of trimming too little, too late, of hoping that structural problems would turn out to be cyclical downturns that might melt away as the economy picked up, all contributed; findings from a state-appointed review team and interviews with past and present city officials also suggest a city that has been badly run for years.

byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

lead_paragraph: Mandatory financial oversight has come as a result of millions in uncollected fees, a flight of the city’s affluent tax base and hopes that downturns might melt away.

headline.seo: For Detroit, a Crisis Born of Bad Decisions and False Hope
headline.main: For Detroit, a Crisis of Bad Decisions and Crossed Fingers
headline.print_headline: For Detroit, a Crisis Born of Bad Decisions and Crossed Fingers
